introduction: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:
text: The Eiffel Tower, completed in 1889 as the entrance arch for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris, stands at 1,083 feet tall. Initially, many Parisians criticized the tower’s design, but it has since become an iconic symbol of Paris and one of the most recognized landmarks in the world. Made of wrought iron, the Eiffel Tower was the tallest man-made structure in the world until the completion of the Chrysler Building in 1930. Over 7 million people visit the Eiffel Tower each year, making it one of the most visited paid monuments in the world. In addition to being a symbol of Paris, the Eiffel Tower also serves as a broadcasting tower and has been used for scientific experiments.
question: The student wants to emphasize the Eiffel Tower’s status as an iconic symbol of Paris. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?
A: The Eiffel Tower, once criticized for its design, has become one of the most recognized landmarks in the world, symbolizing the city of Paris.
B: At 1,083 feet, the Eiffel Tower was the tallest man-made structure in the world until 1930, when it was surpassed by the Chrysler Building.
C: Over 7 million people visit the Eiffel Tower annually, making it one of the most visited paid monuments in the world.
D: The Eiffel Tower serves both as a symbol of Paris and a broadcasting tower, demonstrating its utility beyond its cultural significance.
explanation: Choice A is the best answer because it emphasizes the Eiffel Tower’s iconic status as a symbol of Paris, mentioning its recognition and the transition from being criticized to being beloved. Choice B is incorrect because it focuses on the tower’s height and historical significance, which does not emphasize its symbolic role. Choice C is incorrect because while it discusses the popularity of the Eiffel Tower, it does not address its symbolic status. Choice D is incorrect because it mentions the Eiffel Tower’s functionality but does not focus on its role as a cultural icon.
